body:
Thanks for raising the issue! From looking at your notebook, it seems that your data format does not fit the learning task of time series classification. In your data frame, what do the rows represent, time points or independent samples/instances? 

Take a look at our [tutorial notebook on multivariate time series classification](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/examples/multivariate_time_series_classification.ipynb) to see what the data should look like. To find out more about the different learning tasks that can arise in a temporal data setting, perhaps take a look at our short [paper](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1909.07872.pdf).

@mloning Thank you for the reply and references. I will definitely have a look. 

It is a meteorological dataset for past 20 years. Every row of the dataset represents the data for "a day". I have also uploaded the dataset for reference. 

https://github.com/AASHISHAG/time-series-classification

Can't I use sktime for data of such a kind?

If the rows represent days, and you want to assign a label to each row, then the learning task is time series annotation (as defined in the linked paper above). 

Unfortunately, we don't support time series annotation yet, but it's something we want to cover eventually. Time series classification can in principle be used to solve a time series annotation task (by reduction), but this requires further data transformations to get the data into the right format.

Perhaps the question is, what would the label be?

For the task of (vanilla) time series classification ("TSC"), you need training data in which each row is a pair of (i) a time series, and (ii) a classification label. 

The various methods then will fit/learn a labelling algorithm that, given a time series in a test/deployment set, can assign a label, similar to the label assignment process on the training set.

Furthermore, in vanilla TSC, the different pairs are assumed statistically independent, which might be a doubtful assumption in a generic meteorological setting (at least one that needs careful plausibility checking).

If you can describe what you want to do, we might be able to help diagnose which task you want, and whether it is currently supported by sktime.

@fkiraly : The problem is from a medical setting.

Problem: Given a meteorological condition for the day, I want to predict whether a certain disease would occur or not. I have recordings for past 20 years for 14 features (temperature, pressure etc).

The labels are binary 0 or 1. The classes are imbalanced 0(80%) and 1(20%)

You can refer the dataset here: https://github.com/AASHISHAG/time-series-classification

I thought it to be as a time series classification problem and therefore, applied all traditional ML (random forest, xgboost, logistic regression, naive bayes) and DL (cnn, lstm,autoencoder) but couldn't find good results yet. Any advice on it would be helpful.

Hm, this sounds like either TSC (very well supported), hierarchical/panel TSC (need to apply in certain way), or time series annotation (not supported yet, in dev).

The key differences lie in whether:
(a) measurements are from multiple patients/process, or a single patient/process. If yes: panel setting; if no: not a panel setting.
(b) the occurrence of the disease is plausibly autocorrelated, vs statistically independent over time granularity of days. That is, does it become more or less likely that the disease occurs on day x+1, if you additionally know that it had also occurred on day x (or not)? You can test for this after computing lagged autocorrelations of the disease label. 

If the disease occurrence is auto-correlated, you can de-correlate it by aggregating at a range where independence is plausible (being mindful of binning induced correlation artefacts etc).

In addition, you need to be careful to check for seasonality effects, e.g., by including the time of the year in models.
PS: it would be easier to tell if you didn't only have the data table, but also a full *data dictionary* that describes what is in cols/rows of your data, how entries were recorded, etc.
(removed bug label because I think we've concluded the behaviour is expected if you do not pass the expected data format for the respective task, i.e., not a bug)

rename.from: [BUG] TypeError: object of type 'float' has no len()
rename.to: discussion: use of sktime/TSC for supervised binary label annotation of (possibly auto-correlated) multivariate time series

body:
@fkiraly : Thank you, for the response. I possibly didn't get the update of your reply. I am checking now on auto-correlation and seasonality part.

Below are some insights about the problem and data:

1. It's weather data for a city in Germany for ~20 years and the labels are recorded for multiple patients.
2. The rows in the data table represent a DAY, ordered in a sequence. 1 Jan, 2 Jan, 3 Jan ... for ~20 years.
3. The columns are weather features, like Temp, Pressure, Humidity etc.
4. The labels are 0 or 1.

I believe the occurrence of the disease is related to the past/future also. Therefore, I used LSTM's and also tried CNN's. But I got a ROC of 0.50. I think I should do some feature engineering on the data. I would appreciate if you could provide some guidance.

Ok, what I would recommend in this case is to post here:
- length of the label series
- frequency of the label series (is this daily?)
- acf and pacf (plots) of the label series, you can get these from `pmdarima` from `acf` and `pacf`, plotting preceded by "plot_", in the  `utils` module

Note that if this is medical data or personal data (which I'm not sure about), you may not be legally allowed to post it here without having the necessary ethics approval and/or subject consent - legislation/regulation usually also applies for derived data such as the a auto-correlation (plots).

issue.title: Cheat sheet - "what is your task?" - for self-diagnosis of learning regime

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Somewhat inspired by discussion in issue #197.

Would it not be great if we had a cheat sheet like
https://scikit-learn.org/stable/tutorial/machine_learning_map/index.html
which would allow users to self-diagnose task, statistical learning regime?

"What is your vanilla task" is perhaps easiest to achieve, but one could also think of:
- diagnosing which other tasks are "closeby", e.g., by looking at auto-correlation etc. I.e., "easy" reductions that see promosing.
- diagnosing the case in which the data are not of sufficient sample size or quality
- diagnosing whether the task is supported by sklearn currently, and if not, whether there is an easy manual reduction step

body:
Thank you @fkiraly for your advice. I have taken the approval on the data. I posted below the requested information:
> * length of the label series

Features: 15 Features + 1 added for Seasonality = 15 features (columns) [temp, weather, humidity, wind etc]
Labels: 0 or 1 (1 column - Y)
6135 days (instances/rows)
Data (inital 2000 rows-for reference): https://github.com/AASHISHAG/time-series-classification/blob/master/pre_processed_data.csv

wind_max | wind_ave | rainfall_height | rainfall_form | sunny_hours | snow_height | bedeckungsgrades | dampfdruckes | luftdruck | humidity | air_temp_max | air_temp_min | temp | ground_temp_min | season | date | Y
-- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | --
14.2 | 4.6 | 15 | 4 | 0.2 | 0 | 8 | 7.1 | 983.6 | 86 | 10.6 | -0.8 | 3.6 | -0.8 | 1 | 01-01-03 | 0
21.6 | 5.5 | 9 | 4 | 0.2 | 0 | 7.8 | 10.2 | 967.9 | 88 | 11.8 | 6.8 | 9.2 | 6 | 1 | 01-02-03 | 0
18.7 | 4.4 | 7.4 | 4 | 0 | 0 | 7.8 | 8.5 | 976.2 | 90 | 8.5 | 1.2 | 6.2 | 1 | 1 | 01-03-03 | 0
11 | 5.3 | 0 | 4 | 1.6 | 0 | 6.8 | 4.4 | 988 | 79 | 1.4 | -2.7 | -1.3 | -2.7 | 1 | 01-04-03 | 0
7.8 | 2.7 | 1.2 | 4 | 0.6 | 0 | 7.8 | 4.1 | 993.2 | 84 | -1.7 | -4.6 | -3.2 | -4.8 | 1 | 01-05-03 | 1

> * frequency of the label series (is this daily?)

Yes, from 01-01-03 to 29-06-19

> * acf and pacf (plots) of the label series, you can get these from `pmdarima` from `acf` and `pacf`, plotting preceded by "plot_", in the  `utils` module

Plots can be found here: https://github.com/AASHISHAG/time-series-classification/blob/master/acf_pacf.ipynb

Alright, this is helpful.
I gather from your worksheet that there is *a single target time series*, that is, only one instance.

From the looks of it, thus, your vanilla task is:
- event modelling (because the "condition" happens rarely, and there are many days in-between without)
- with exogeneous variables (= weather etc) that of are time series type

The standard approach for event modelling is temporal point processes, in this case you probably want one with an intensity function that is conditional on the past labels as well as the history of the exogeneous variables.
Your typical "nulls" (= baselines) are homogenous Poisson process (there is a constant event risk and it doesn't depend on the exogeneous variables) and inhomogenous Poisson process (event risk varies over time, but unrelated to anything).

This type of learning task is currently not supported by sktime (event modelling requires the skpro interface which is currently under major re-work by @jesellier; *contributions are welcome!*). I'm also not sure whether there exists an off-shelf option for temporal point processes with exogeneity, though you might be able to build one manually using tensorflow probability or a Bayesian probabilistic programming language (both options sound tedious, other ideas/suggestions are welcome).

However, there may be some easy options to reduce to time series classification/regression, since it doesn't look like the label series is strongly auto-correlated, and the exogeneous variables seem to auto-correlate in the order of months (difficult to tell since you cut off the plots after a couple weeks):
- make monthly bins, and the label is the number of events in that month. Try to predict the number from the series in (probabilistic or deterministic) time series count regression.
- pair up "the past month of time series" with the label for that day (for all days), consider this a time series classification problem where you predict hte label for the day from the past month series.
- instead of the event 0/1 labels, consider the series of waiting times (time until next event). Pair up each waiting time with 1 month of series that leads up to the last event before the wait; try to predict the next waiting time by (probabilistic or deterministic) time series regression.
- the same, but doing this for every day and predicting the waiting time until the next event

For evaluation, you have to keep in mind that the sample of prediction errors (samples of squared loss, classification loss, etc) is not an independent sample. For comparisons to the baselines and dummys, you may have to correct critical differences for auto-correlation. A common effective sample size correction is "divide by 1+2*sum-over-acf" (acf not including the lag-0-term), this is under assumption of stationary residuals.

The risk going down this route is perhaps loss of statistical power, i.e., you might not find any evidence that the weather etc relate to the event happening. Though of course that might be the case anyway (which is perhaps the key hypothesis to check for your investigation).

Presuming this discussion has now concluded (please shout if not), closing the issue.
#210 is arising from this, and the specific tasks and reductions occurring here are subject of ongoing development.
